SLIDE #: 2 || Learning Objectives for this Section: 
 Understand the purpose and clinical context of toxicology. 
 Learn the different clinical samples typically tested. 
 Learn about the variety of drugs and poisons that are tested 
 Understand the screen and confirmation tests and their purposes.

SLIDE #: 3 || Toxicology 
 Purpose of Toxicology Testing: 
 To detect, identify, and possibly measure, in various biological fluids, drugs and poisons which may or may not be suspected to be present. 
 Substance could be illicit or prescribed

SLIDE #: 4 || Patients 
 Emergency

SLIDE #: 5 || Analytical Approaches 
  Tests for specific drugs/poisons (e.g. drugs of abuse) when clinical  information points directly to them 
 General analyses for any or all drugs/ poisons when information on the case is limited 
 first is direct testing - test  for specific drug 
 second to see classes of drugs they've been on or broad panel like mass spec to look at 100s

SLIDE #: 6 || Interpretation of Analyses Serum/Plasma: 
 Specimen of choice to measure drug levels 
 Can measure level of intoxication 
 Contains parent drugs and some metabolites 
 Analysis rather involved because of complex matrix including large amounts of lipid and protein present 
 Drugs can be present in low concentration 
 main sample type is serum/plasma if you want to measure drug levels in patient 
 - can tell you about intoxication or impact of having drug in system 
 - more complex matrix and harder to test for because of lots of serum proteins and lipids in the sample 
 - requires more sensitive technology like liquid chromatography or mass spec because drugs are often present in low concentrations

SLIDE #: 7 || Interpretation of Analyses - Urine 
 Indicates exposure (what drugs taken) but exact timeline of when the compound was ingested 
 Cannot measure level of intoxication 
 Contains mostly drug metabolites (sometimes parent drug) 
 Less complex matrix results in simpler analysis due to very small amounts of lipid and protein present 
 the more common sample type is urine - this is because the question is usually 'what did the person take' rather than how much they took 
 - doesn't tell you much about amount taken or when they took it (doesn't tell you a lot about intoxication) 
 - most cases you only detect drug metabolites 
 - it's a simpler matrix - less protein and fat - therefore easier to measure drug of interest

SLIDE #: 8 || Interpretation of Analyses – Gastric Fluid 
 relatively infrequently requested 
  invasive specimen 
 no advantage over serum or urine 
 another fluid type that could be tested is gastric fluid  
 - this is very rarely tested because so invasive to retreive and not a lot of advantage  
 - e.g. known ingestion or found inconscious with empty pill bottle and it is thought they consumed 100s of pills

SLIDE #: 9 || Interpretation of Analyses  - Hair and Meconium 
 These testing matrices are used to determine long term exposure to drugs 
 Hair testing can be used to identify a timeline for drug abuse or compliance. (e.g. was this a one-time exposure or has there been chronic exposure) 
 Meconium tests are requested in neonates when there is concern regarding long term exposure to drugs in utero. 
 Not clinically useful for acute management – TAT is too long – weeks 
 Usually only requested by CAS 
 another sample type is hair and meconium (first stool formed in baby ~ black stool that baby has) 
 - both are good matrices for long term exposure to drugs 
 - hair testing can be used as a timeline - closer to scalp = more recent drug use 
 - meconium testing is done on neonates and often when it is during concern regarding exposure in utero (medications or drug of abuse mom consumed during pregnancy) 
 - tests are only done by specialized labs

SLIDE #: 10 || Types of Drugs /Poisons 
 1. Alcohols (ethanol, methanol, isopropanol and acetone, ethylene glycol) 
 2. Drugs of Abuse (cannabinoids, opiates, cocaine, amphetamines, phencyclidine [PCP]) 
 3. Over-the-counter Drugs (salicylate, acetaminophen, pseudoephedrine, diphenhydramine) 
 4. Prescription Drugs (antidepressants, benzodiazepines, barbiturates) 
 5. Sexual assault drugs (gammahydroxybutyrate, flunitrazepam, ketamine) 
 6. Heavy Metals (Pb, As, Hg) 
 2. can be street drugs or pharmaceutical drugs

SLIDE #: 18 || Unexplained   OGAP 
 An unexplained OGAP >10 mmol/L strongly suggests presence of something in addition to ethanol

SLIDE #: 19 || Serum Osmolality Gap (OGAP) 
 Ethylene glycol is toxic at only 3.2 mmol/L

 If unexplained OGAP <=6 mmol/L, we encourage clinical staff to cancel the methanol/isopropanol screen but not a glycol screen

SLIDE #: 27 || Terminology 
 Screening Test: 
 initial test which distinguishes a negative result from a presumptive positive

SLIDE #: 28 || Terminology 
 Presumptive Positive: 
 positive screen test result not yet validated by a confirmation  test 
 in most cases, confirmation test/methodoly is by some type of mass spec method where you have definitive peak/fragmentation pattern compared to standard and you know it was present  
 most often come from immunoassay or POC

SLIDE #: 29 || Terminology 
 Confirmation Test: 
 definitive test which conclusively establishes the 
 presumptive positive screen result as a true or false 
 positive 
 confirm. testing normally done with mass spec method

SLIDE #: 30 || Terminology 
 True Positive:  
    a positive screening test result which has been validated by a positive confirmation test result 
 both screening methodology and confirmation test both say drug is there in sample

SLIDE #: 31 || Terminology 
 False Positive: 
     a presumptive positive screening test result which has been invalidated by a negative confirmation test result 
 normally due to cross reactivity to some other drug in sample

SLIDE #: 36 || Causes Of False Positive Immunoassay Drug Screen Results 
 [Drug] is close to but below the cutoff conc’n 
 Presence of interfering substances  
 (usually other drugs) 
 due to interfering substance (some other drug) 
 or drug gets close to cut-off 
 - be a little bit higher than cut off but in confirmation testing its not high enough to reach cut off 
 - could be due to the fact that parent drug/other drugs in the same class collectively bind and react in immunoassay therefore collectively theyre all greater in cutt off but when looking at them individually they might not meet it

SLIDE #: 37 || Confirmation Methods 
 greater analytical sensitivity than the screen 
 based on a different chemical principle 
 HPLC,  GC,  triple quad LCMS,   GC/MS 
 measure lower concentrations and definiatively tell compound's presence 
 method is based on mass spec usually which is a different pricniple than immunoassay 
 could be done by HPLC or GC but more commonly done by LCMS or GC/MS

SLIDE #: 38 || Screen Confirmation 
 Positive screen result for drugs of abuse and prescription drugs 
 Indeterminate screen result may be close but below the cut-off level, 
 False positive screen result due to cross reactivity or interference from other drugs is always possible 
 It is not necessary to do confirmations on all samples containing drugs, for example: 
 Nicotine (unless insurance testing) 
 Caffeine 
 Therapeutic drugs for which there are assays available 
 Prescribed drugs (known to be taken by patient).

SLIDE #: 39 || Criteria for Confirmation Testing: 
 Presumptive positive immunoassay screen result 
 Any uncertainty in the identification of a drug in the initial drug screen (e.g. GC/MS or LC/MS/MS) 
 Request from patient care giver 
 if you need to know the true positive then you need to do a confirmation test

SLIDE #: 40 || Criteria for Confirmation Testing: 
 Reality check: 
 In the clinical setting, confirmation testing cannot be done in real time for Emerg. Dept. needs 
 And so many drug screens are ordered by ED. 
    Tox lab confirmation tests cannot keep up anyway 
 Confirmation testing done on request only. 
 Absolutely necessary in forensic toxicology testing to determine cause of death with certainty 
 when determining if to do a confirmation test, do a reality check, figure out if you need it and if it clinically impacts the case 
 usually by ED, they want to determine what drug the overdose was and that's all they need to know to treat 
 - ED though might be acting before the screening result 
 ED also orders them for patients admitted to psychiatry - to figure out what the patient came into the ED On  
 confirmation testing requires more investment of time and greater TAT therefore no clinical use to ED  
 confirmation testing done in certain clinical situations like pain clinics and forensic investigation

SLIDE #: 41 || Toxidromes 
 clinically, they are assessing toxidromes (clinical parameters they can measure to assess what potential drug a patient overdosed on) 
 - they do this along with screening methodology sent to core lab  
 toxidromes - clinically assess respiratory rate, HR, blood pressure, size of pupils, temperature, bowel, sweat and energy 
 you can clinically classify drug overdose into one of these five categories which can dictate what the treatment should be 
 all they need from the lab is a screen result to confirm that clinical picture and results match that they are on the right track 
 anticholinergic - basically fight or flight response by someone 
 noloxone is therapy for opioid overdose

SLIDE #: 63 || Case 3 - Conclusion 
 After doing a comprehensive laboratory investigation including UDS, toxic alcohol screen and lithium level for TDM. The patient was found to have a critical Lithium level 2.5 mmol/L (RI 0.4 – 1.3) with mild acute on chronic kidney disease Cre 214. 
 He was on a stable lithium dose over the last few years and denies any intentional overdose and was taking his lithium as prescribed. Lithium was held until the lithium levels came down to below the reference range 0.4 mmol/L (6 days). 
 Recommendation from Nephrology, Clinical Pharmacology, and Poison Centre was to hold the Lithium and give IV fluids, acute dialysis is not indicated to facilitate lithium clearance.  
 Monitor kidney function with frequent volume assessments and watch for lithium induced diabetes insipidus . 
 The differential for his presentation would include lithium toxicity versus worsening of his underlying neurological disorder, secondary to decreased oral intake, GI symptoms, and hypovolumeia. 
 Patient was referred to Psychiatry for reassessment of Bipolar disorder and lithium dosing

SLIDE #: 64 || Lithium Toxicity 
 Lithium toxicity treatment guidelines for Dialysis:  
 Lithium level >6 mmol/L: any patient 
 Lithium level >4 mmol/L: any patient on chronic lithium therapy 
 Lithium level between 2.5 and 4 mmol/L: any patient with severe neurologic symptoms, renal insufficiency, or unstable hemodynamically or neurologically 
 Lithium level <2.5 mmol/L: hemodialysis indicated only for patients with end-stage renal disease or patients whose lithium levels increase after admission or who fail to reach a lithium level below 1 mmol/L in 30 h 
 Ref Dr B. Kapur CSCC List Serv
